channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkey to Continue Withdrawal of Troops From Northern Iraq
item.description: The Iraqi government has called on Turkey to pull out all of its troops, saying it never invited their participation in an international effort to train forces to fight the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: In ISIS Strategy, U.S. Weighs Risk to Civilians
item.description: As President Obama pledged to intensify the anti-Islamic State campaign, he acknowledged the challenges in targeting militants who, in Raqqa, Syria, and elsewhere, inhabit the same spaces as civilians.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Kurdish militiamen in October in Ein Eissa, Syria, one of the nearest bases to Raqqa, where Islamic State fighters stay in proximity to civilians, which makes a United States airstrike risky.

item.title: A Spaniard Selling Lottery Fortune
item.description: In a nation of the heaviest lottery spenders in the world, hundreds of thousands flock to its most popular ticket office, in the village of Sort, which means “luck” in Catalan.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Xavier Gabriel at his lottery office, the Golden Witch, in the village of Sort.

item.title: U.S. and Cuba at Odds Over Exodus of the Island’s Doctors
item.description: An escape route was set up by the United States government, under a 2006 program that offers American residency to Cuban medical workers posted overseas.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT and FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. José Angel Sánchez, now in Paterson, N.J., saw his medical school training as a route out of Cuba to the United States.

item.title: Russia May Aid ‘Comrade Tourists’ Who Were Really Soldiers
item.description: The Soviet Union managed to sneak thousands of soldiers into Syria in 1983 during the Lebanese civil war, in which Syria, their ally, was involved.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valery S. Anisimov, one of the soldiers sent secretly to help Syria during the Lebanon civil war, is trying to have the men recognized as combat veterans.

item.title: Norway Offers Migrants a Lesson in How to Treat Women
item.description: A pioneering program seeks to combat sexual violence by helping new immigrants adapt to a society whose sexual norms they may find confusing.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees from Sudan took part in a class dealing with violence against women, at a refugee center in Lunde, Norway.

item.title: Batang Grasslands Journal: A Showcase of Tibetan Culture Serves Chinese Political Goals
item.description: Horse festivals on the Tibetan plateau are not just about equestrian prowess — they are political affairs with a propaganda goal.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Internet Firms Urged to Limit Work of Anwar al-Awlaki
item.description: The inflammatory videos and bomb-making instructions of Anwar al-Awlaki have turned up as a powerful influence in terrorism investigations.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:credit: Site Intelligence Group, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Anwar al-Awlaki was a United States-born cleric and propagandist for Al Qaeda.

item.title: U.S. Airstrike Killed Iraqis by Accident, Officials Say
item.description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter did not offer a detailed explanation for the errant airstrike, which the Iraqi government said killed at least nine Iraqi soldiers, but said, “It seemed to be a mistake that involved both sides.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Mourners carried the body of one of the soldiers killed in the strike near Falluja on Friday.

item.title: News Analysis: Syrian Peace Plan Offers Some Hope, but Has Plenty of Pitfalls
item.description: After four and a half years, bitterly divided world powers have finally agreed on a peace plan for Syria.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria with his wife, Asma, ata Christmas choral presentation at a church in Damascus on Friday.

item.title: Gandhi Family Pledges to Fight Corruption Case Filed by a Political Riva
item.description: The criminal charge, filed by a legal gadfly who is also a senior member of the Bharatiya Janata Party, claims that Sonia and Rahul Gandhi illegally gained control over real estate that belonged to a defunct party newspaper and that is now worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Sonia and Rahul Gandhi, center, arrived at a New Delhi courthouse to apply for bail on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Bomber Mistakenly Flew Near Disputed Island in South China Sea
item.description: The B-52 flew within two nautical miles of an artificial island China built in the South China Sea, the Pentagon said. China called it a provocation.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Licio Gelli, Italian Financier and Cabal Leader, Dies at 96
item.description: Mr. Gelli was a self-professed fascist accused of being the grandmaster of a secret society that plotted a right-wing coup, among other crimes and scandals.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: World Briefing: Inquiry Is Promised About Airstrike in Iraq by Coalition Fighting ISIS
item.description: A statement from the American military, which promised an investigation, said the strike might have led to the deaths of Iraqi soldiers.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil’s Finance Minister Replaced
item.description: The minister, Joaquim Levy, had been in charge of spearheading austerity measures and returning the country to fiscal and economic health.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: World Briefing: Russia Expelling Polish Journalist
item.description: The move is retaliation after a Russian reporter had been stripped of his right to live in Poland amid suspicions of espionage.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: After Years of War in Syria, U.N. Passes Resolution on Talks
item.description: For the first time in the nearly five-year civil war in Syria, the Security Council backed a process for resolving the conflict.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: An injured man at a field hospital in Douma, Syria, this month, following what activists said was an airstrike by forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: U.S. Delivers Art to Iran That Had Been Impounded Since 1979
item.description: The artwork, which Iran said included drawings by Americans, was blocked from export after the 1979 revolution and Tehran hostage crisis.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: ISIS Building ‘Little Nests’ in Afghanistan, U.S. Defense Secretary Warns
item.description: The presence of the militant group adds to the complex array of threats confronting Afghan forces and their international partners, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Friday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: China’s Renminbi Declines After Being Named a Global Currency, Posing Challenges
item.description: If China’s currency falls too steeply, the volatility could prompt traders to place large bets on further depreciation, making the decline harder to control.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Uighur herders in China count renminbi at a livestock trading market. A weakening economy is taking a toll on the currency’s value as money leaves the country.
